newsitem.title: FRANCE: Chirac to wish gloomy France a happy New Year.
newsitem.headline: Chirac to wish gloomy France a happy New Year.

text.p: President Jacques Chirac will be struggling to give gloomy French citizens reasons to believe in a brighter future when he broadcasts his traditional New Year message to the nation on Tuesday.
It will be Chirac's second television appearance in less than a month.

In a lengthy interview on December 12, he appealed for understanding for the centre-right government's austerity policies but failed to boost his low popularity significantly. Recent opinion polls have shown only a slight rise in his approval rating and that of his embattled prime minister, Alain Juppe.
French presidents usually say little of substance in their New Year messages, which last just a few minutes and are broadcast just before the evening news programmes.
Chirac will be eager to boost national morale at the end of a year which, according to the conservative, pro-government daily Le Figaro, has been a dark one for France.

"Unemployment has not dropped, poverty has not been defeated, the weight of public services and taxes has not been lightened," wrote Figaro columnist Jean d'Ormesson. "And French people are not happy."

While attempting to convince viewers that better times lie ahead, Chirac should also use Tuesday's address to try to correct a personal image which, according to former presidential adviser Bernard Rideau, is a poor one.
"Chirac seems transfixed (by the media)", Rideau, former media adviser to ex-president Valery Giscard d'Estaing, told the daily Liberation in an interview on Monday.
"He says himself that he does not like television. He appears likeable and close to the people's problems...but he fails to appear as a man with an experience of power and competence," Rideau added.
